creator: kazue@hiro-tan.dhs.org
text:
When I create an application that inserts japanese (double-byte) data
to the database, if the data is entered as a non-ASCII data,
it end up junk in the database. Looks like only
ASCII characters are allowed as POSTed data.

creator: marc.saegesser@apropos.com
text:
I do this sort of thing my application and it works fine.  Note that posted 
data will arrive still encoded in using the client's charset (i.e. Shift_JIS, 
ISO-8859-2, etc.) and it is up to the servlet author to convert this into the 
UNICODE internal representation used by Java.  Most servlet texts will describe 
various ways to accomplish this.

creator: kazue@hiro-tan.dhs.org
text:
Well, I agree that there are workarounds for this problem; what I do is to 
add the following code for setting the form value;
> new String(request.getParameter("foo").getBytes("ISO-8859-1"), "SJIS")
However, it would be nice if we could use any encoding without adding anything 
to our servlets.
I believe currently tomcat uses 
"javax.servlet.http.HttpUtils.parsePostData() " to process the posted data,
which seems to me very archaic because most browsers these days accepts charsets
other than ASCII.
I feel Tomcat should have its own version of this routine that honors the
charset parameter of the the ContentType header sent by the browser.
Won't be addressed in Tomcat 3.2.2 but will be evaluated for later releases.
creator: marc.saegesser@apropos.com
